I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  an  economic  contact  mission  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in 
June 2006, the Government of Brunei Darussalam (Brunei) requested ADB to provide technical 
assistance  (TA)  for  the  establishment  of  a  well-functioning  capital  market  supported  by  a 
modernized payment and settlement system, to promote a more diversified economy. ADB 
fielded a fact-finding mission in November 2006 to discuss and reach an understanding with the 
Government about the objectives and scope of the proposed TA, the terms of reference for 
consultants, and cost and implementation arrangements.1 The design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  While per capita gross domestic product (GDP) in Brunei is comparatively high by 
regional standards, economic activity is highly concentrated in the oil and gas sector, which 
accounts for roughly half of GDP, more than 90% of export earnings, and between 75% and 
90% of government revenue. The price volatility of oil and gas, and the finite and declining 
nature of reserves, means that the economy must diversify for more sustainable economic 
growth, more stable government revenue, and more varied employment opportunities for the 
growing and increasingly better educated labor force. 
 
3.  The Government has long recognized the implications of overdependence on oil and 
gas, and has made economic diversification a key goal in successive national development 
plans. Among the challenges the country faces in this regard are (i) the small size of the 
domestic market, (ii) the Government’s dominant role in the economy, and (iii) the limited base 
of entrepreneurial and managerial talent available in the country. 
 
4.  In  the  national  development  plan  published  most  recently  by  the  Government,  the 
development of the financial sector is a key part of economic diversification — both as a sector 
in itself and as a means of facilitating investment in other sectors.3 The capital market, in 
particular, is seen as a niche area that will allow Brunei to (i) promote a more efficient and 
robust financial sector by providing an alternative to bank lending and reducing dependence on 
it,  (ii)  attract  foreign  direct  investment  by  offering  an  avenue  for  divestment,  (iii) make 
government-linked enterprises more competitive and eventually privatize them, and (iv) raise 
long-term financing for major infrastructure projects. 
 
5.  The financial sector in Brunei is relatively small (about 4% of GDP in 2006) and is 
dominated by the banking sector. In 2007, there were 8 banks (6 foreign branches and 2 local 
banks),  4  finance  companies,  1  Islamic  Trust  Fund,  13  insurance  companies  (including  3 
takaful)4, 33 money changers, and 34 remittance companies.  The Islamic Trust Fund and the 
finance companies operate like banks (they take deposits and give loans) but do not offer 
current accounts or demand deposits. Banks in Brunei take deposits from the private sector and

6.  Because the Government has such a dominant role in the economy and the private 
sector is underdeveloped, few loans are made to the corporate sector and most borrowing is 
consumer related.5 The limited absorptive capacity of the private sector and the lack of other 
domestic opportunities for investment create huge liquidity in the banking system, most of which 
is invested abroad (primarily in Singapore). 
 
7.  Important  gaps  in  laws  and  regulations  and  in  infrastructure  and  institutional 
arrangements hamper the financial sector. The main check clearing system for banks is run by 
the Hong Kong Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited (HSBC) in Brunei, which was appointed 
for this purpose by the Brunei Association of Banks. The system handles an average of 3,500–
4,500 checks daily. There is no system for large-value payments. Checks are cleared manually, 
on a T+3 basis. This is slow by modern standards, where T+1 or even same-day settlement is 
the norm.  
 
8.  The legal and regulatory basis for securities settlement is transaction-specific and is 
defined through contractual agreements with the appointed primary dealers. This arrangement 
does  not  promote  the  participation  of  domestic  retail  investors,  the  development  of  more 
complex securities, or access to international investors. 
 
9.  Recognizing that it must deal with a wide range of issues before it can develop a 
well-functioning capital market, the Government intends to achieve this goal over the next 10 
years through various initiatives. These include: (i) modernizing the payment and settlement 
system;  (ii) improving  corporate  governance  by  strengthening  accounting  and  auditing 
standards, among other things; (iii) reinforcing the legal, regulatory, and supervisory framework; 
and (iv) boosting institutional capacity. 
 
10.  To promote the country as an international financial center, Brunei needs to effectively 
position itself alongside established financial centers like Singapore and Hong Kong, China, 
which  also  offer  economic  and  political  stability,  well-developed  infrastructure,  high-quality 
education and health facilities, multilingual professionals, and freedom from exchange controls, 
besides having a much larger population. Two main factors distinguish Brunei from these other 
markets: (i) the absence of personal income taxes, and (ii) strong leadership and commitment to 
the development of Islamic financial products. 
 
11.  The Government receives technical assistance and advisory support in financial sector 
development from the International Monetary Fund (consolidation of financial sector regulation 
and monetary authority), the World Bank (asset management and pension fund administration), 
and the Islamic Development Bank (Islamic financial legislation and human resource capacity 
building).  The  Government  has  also  received  technical  assistance  in  insurance  from  the 
Commonwealth  Secretariat  and  is  receiving  assistance  in  bond  market  development  from 
Nomura  Research  Institute  through  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN) 
Secretariat.6 
 
                                                 
5  The Government also lends to the private sector. The Treasury Department provides interest-free car loans and 
housing loans to government officials. The Resettlement Department provides land and houses with 20-year 
interest-free mortgages for residents. 
6  The ASEAN project will be closely coordinated with implementation of this TA.

3 
12.  Recent initiatives of the Government to promote capital market development include the 
following: 
 
(i)  Adopting a comprehensive legal framework for the financial sector, including the 
new Banking Order and Insurance Order passed in 2006, which incorporates 
international best-practice standards and regulates both conventional and Islamic 
financial products.  
(ii)  Setting  up  the  Brunei  International  Financial  Centre  (BIFC),  an  international 
financial center that extends flexible business facilities, including tax-free status. 
BIFC has attracted international firms offering conventional as well as Islamic 
financial products. So far, six international banks, nine private mutual funds, and 
ten investment advisers have been licensed.  
(iii)  Establishing a Financial Intelligence Unit in February 2007 to combat money 
laundering activities and other suspicious transactions. 
(iv)  Successfully issuing twelve series of short-term (91-day) and one year Islamic 
government bonds (Sukuk Iljarah)7 totaling B$1.050 billion. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The TA will support economic diversification in Brunei by developing a more efficient and 
robust financial sector. The expected outcome is a functional capital market supported by a 
modernized payment and settlement system. The TA focuses on diagnostic studies to formulate 
a capital market masterplan and a payment and settlement blueprint.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The  TA  includes  two  components.  Component  A  will  focus  on  capital  market 
development and component B on the modernization of the payment and settlement system. 
Implementation activities will be closely coordinated to take advantage of synergies and avoid 
overlaps between consultant deliverables. The TA will fund consultants with expertise in capital 
market  development,  capital  market  laws  and  regulations,  bond  markets,  payment  and 
settlement systems, and financial sector information technology. Roundtable discussions will be 
held with Government officials and stakeholders and international experts will be invited to 
share international best practices to facilitate discussion and agreement on reform proposals. 
 
15.  Key activities in component A will be as follows: 
 
(i)  Conducting  diagnostic  studies  to  assess  impediments  to  capital  market 
development  arising  from  inadequacies  in  laws  and  regulations,  institutional 
arrangements, supporting infrastructure, and technical capacity. 8  
(ii)  Preparing  a  capital  market  master  plan,  including  recommendations  and  a 
related action plan for improving the legal and regulatory framework, institutional 
arrangements, infrastructure, and capacity over the short, medium, and long 
term.

(iii)  Developing an implementation strategy. 
  
16.  Key activities in component B will be as follows: 
 
(i)  Conducting of diagnostic studies to assess impediments to the development of a 
modernized payment and settlement system arising from inadequacies in laws 
and  regulations,  institutional  arrangements,  supporting  infrastructure,  and 
technical capacity.  
(ii)  Preparing a blueprint for a modernized payment and settlement system, including 
recommendations and a related action plan for improving the legal and regulatory 
framework, institutional arrangements, infrastructure for payment and settlement, 
and related capacity over the short, medium, and long term. 
(iii)  Developing an implementation strategy. 
 
17.  The team leader will closely coordinate the preparation of the studies and the related 
recommendations, all of which will be reflected in the capital market master plan and the related 
payment and settlement blueprint.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The initial cost of the TA to be funded by the Government through ADB is estimated to 
be US$600,000.9 Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The Ministry of Finance will be the Executing Agency (EA) for the TA and will form a 
steering committee, chaired by the permanent secretary (monetary) of the EA, to oversee 
implementation. The steering committee will appoint a project director for each component of 
the TA.   
 
20.  The TA will require 16 person-months of international consultant input. The international 
consultants  will  include  a  capital  market  development  expert,  a  capital  market  legal  and 
regulatory expert, a bond market expert, a payment and settlement expert, and a financial 
sector information technology expert. The TA is expected to be implemented over 12 months, 
from June 2008 to May 2009. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
21.  The consultants will be hired individually or through a firm by ADB through quality-based 
selection, according to the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time 
to time). All service payments under the Project will conform to ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time).  
 
22.  The  consultants  may  organize  study  tours  of  institutional  arrangements,  rules,  and 
procedures for the capital market, as well as payment and settlement arrangements, in selected 
countries  to  build  capacity  in  connection  with  the  preparation  of  the  master  plan  and  the 
blueprint and other related forward-looking activities. The countries will be carefully selected for 
their relevance to the economic and financial status of Brunei. 
 
                                                 
9  ADB will recruit consultants, review and comment on consultant deliverables, pay the consultants from its ordinary 
capital  resources,  bill  the  Government  for  all  direct  costs  (which  the  Government  has  agreed  to  promptly 
reimburse), and arrange and participate in tripartite meetings with the Government. ADB has agreed to waive 
financing charges incurred for the use of ADB funds for this project.

5 
23.  The consultants will prepare detailed workplans within 2 weeks of mobilization. The 
workplans will include timetables for deliverables defined for each component of the TA in 
consultation with the EA and coordinated by the team leader. The consultants shall report 
monthly on the progress of implementation of key activities in their workplans. Draft final reports 
will be submitted by the deadline specified in the workplans after comments from the EA and 
ADB are incorporated. Tripartite meetings will be held before the draft final report is finalized. 
The final report, incorporating the comments of the EA and ADB during and after the tripartite 
meeting, will be submitted at the end of the services.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision  of  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  US$600,000  on  a 
reimbursable basis to the Government of Brunei Darussalam for the Development of the Capital 
Market and a Modernized Payment and Settlement System, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

  OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International  Capital  Market  Development  Expert  and  Team  Leader 
(5 person-months) 
1.  The team leader is expected to have significant and recent expertise (10–15 years) in 
capital market development, including experience with Islamic financial products.  Experience in 
the Asia and Pacific region is preferable. The team leader will be responsible for preparing the 
draft  capital  market  master  plan,  including  the  related  diagnostic  studies,  and  facilitating 
agreement on new initiatives to address policy, legal, regulatory, supervisory, institutional, and 
capacity constraints to the development of the capital market in Brunei. The team leader’s 
duties will include the following: 
   
(i)  With inputs from other international experts and in coordination with the work 
undertaken by the Government and other development partners, oversee the 
preparation of diagnostic studies on the following:1 
(a)   potential issuers of debt and equity products over the short, medium, and 
long term (e.g., export-oriented sectors, government-linked companies, 
venture capital funds, foreign firms); 
(b)   the  current  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for  the  capital  market 
(conventional and Islamic products), to identify gaps and impediments to 
the  development  of  the  capital  market  on  the  basis  of  best-practice 
principles;  
(c)  institutional arrangements for capital market development to identify gaps 
and impediments to the development of the capital market on the basis of 
best-practice principles; 
(d)  supporting  infrastructure  for  capital  market  development  (secondary 
trading, securities clearance and settlement, etc); and 
(e)  capacity (technical and human resource) for capital market development, 
including investor awareness. 
 (ii)  Taking into account the findings of the diagnostic studies, the nascent nature and 
small  size of  the  market,  and  the  limited  population,  prepare  a  draft  capital 
market master plan that (a) identifies the role of a well-functioning capital market 
and its value to the economy; (b) highlights effective ways to position the market; 
and (c) specifies the actions (legal and regulatory, institutional, infrastructure, 
capacity) needed to achieve this objective, including a related timetable (with 
milestones for the short, medium, and long term).  
(iii)  Coordinate  the  preparation  of  the  payment  and  settlement  blueprint  by  the 
payment and settlement expert. 
(iv)  Organize workshops to discuss the draft master plan and the draft payment and 
settlement blueprint. 
(v)  Organize study tours to appropriate markets to clarify policy options and enhance 
related capacity. 
(vi)  Oversee the finalization of the draft master plan and blueprint, including clear 
benchmarks to track progress in the development of the capital market and the 
modernization of the payment and settlement system.

B.  International Legal and Regulatory Expert (3 person-months)2 
2.  This expert should have significant experience in capital market regulation in developed 
and  developing  markets,  including  regulation  of  payment  and  settlement  systems,  and  a 
working knowledge of the implementation of the best-practice principles and objectives of the 
International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) in securities regulation and the 
recommendations of the Group of 30 (G-30) related to payment and settlement. Experience in 
the Asia and Pacific region and in markets that offer Islamic financial products is preferable.  
The expert’s duties will include the following: 
 
(i)  In coordination with the team leader and the payment and settlement systems 
expert, prepare a draft diagnostic study on the legal and regulatory framework for 
the capital market (equity and debt, conventional and Islamic financial products, 
and related tax issues) and for payment and settlement, to clarify gaps and 
impediments to the development of the capital market and the modernization of 
the payment and settlement system on the basis of best-practice principles.   
(ii)  Prepare a report that sets forth the findings and the recommended legal and 
regulatory  reforms  needed  to  support  a  functional  capital  market  and  a 
modernized  payment  and  settlement  system.  The  report  should  identify 
impediments to full implementation of IOSCO Principles and include copies of 
relevant  legislation  adopting  best-practice  standards  from  other  common-law 
jurisdictions 
(iii)  Support the team leader in all matters relating to laws and regulations in the 
capital market and the payment and settlement system. 
(iv)  Assist the team leader in organizing and implementing workshops and seminars 
where legal and regulatory issues are discussed. 
(v)  Prepare a workplan, progress reports, and deliverables as required by the team 
leader.

C.  International Bond Market Expert (2 person-months) 
3.  The expert should have significant experience in primary and secondary bond markets. 
Knowledge of Islamic financial products is preferable.  The expert’s duties will include the 
following: 
 
(i)  Review reports, studies and recommendations to promote local bond market  
development prepared by other development partners 
(ii)  As part of the overall capital market development strategy and in coordination 
with the Government and other development partners, assist the team leader and 
other  international  experts  in  preparing  recommendations  to  address  legal, 
regulatory,  institutional,  and  related  infrastructure  and  capacity  gaps  and 
impediments  to  bond  market  development  on  the  basis  of  best-practice 
principles. Recommendations should among others promote the development of 
(a) a strategy for issuing government securities that prepares the market for 
regular  issues,  targeted  to  specific  maturities,  to  set  a  benchmark  for  other 
government issues, initially targeting shorter maturities; (b) measures to anchor 
the strategy for issuing government paper within a sound fiscal policy stance and 
a  medium-term  expenditure  framework;  (c) a  domestic  yield  curve;  (d)  a 
secondary market for government securities, including a review of the primary 
dealer function and the development of recommended incentives to improve 
secondary market trading, including the rights and obligations of primary dealers; 
and (e)  interbank and money markets.  
(iii)  Support the team leader in all matters relating to bond market development.  
(iv)  Assist  the  team  leader  in  organizing  related  workshops  and  seminars,  and 
participating in these workshops and seminars. 
(v)  Prepare a workplan, progress reports, and deliverables, as required by the team 
leader.  
 
D.  International Payment and Settlement Expert (3 person-months) 
4.  The expert should have a strong background in banking and finance and significant 
operational experience in payment and settlement systems, including securities settlement. 
Experience in the Asia and Pacific region is preferable. The expert’s duties will include the 
following: 
 
(i)  In  coordination  with  the  team  leader  and  other  international  experts,  and  in 
consultation  with  Government  and  private  sector  stakeholders,  prepare 
diagnostic  studies  on  the  following:  (a)  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for 
payment and settlement, to identify gaps and impediments to the development of 
the  framework  on  the  basis  of  best-practice  principles;  (b)  institutional 
arrangements for payment and settlement, to identify gaps and impediments to 
the development of such arrangements on the basis of best-practice principles; 
(c) supporting infrastructure for payment and settlement; and (d) human resource 
capacity to implement modernized payment and settlement systems.  
(ii)  In  coordination  with  the  team  leader,  other  international  experts,  and  the 
Government and its other development partners that are supporting financial 
sector  development,  prepare  a  blueprint  of  sequenced  reform  activities  for 
establishing  a  modernized  payment,  settlement,  and  clearance  system  for 
financial transactions and traded securities. The draft blueprint should take stock 
of what is available at present and contain a road map of proposed actions for

resource  capacity,  and  supporting  infrastructure,  including  key  actions  to  be

(iii)  In coordination with the team leader, organize several workshops, and prepare 
the related materials, to present the diagnostic report and build consensus on the 
various aspects of the draft blueprint, and use the training workshops to increase 
the understanding and capacity of the identified counterparts related to their 
depository, issuing and payment agent, registrar, custodian, transfer agent, and 
payment and settlement functions.  
(iv)  In coordination with the financial sector information technology expert, develop a 
framework for a suitable information and communications technology platform to 
support the payment and settlement system, the settlement and clearance of 
traded securities, and the proposed e-government integrated payment gateway.  
(v)  Assist the team leader in organizing related workshops, and participate in the 
workshops. 
(vi)  Prepare a workplan, progress reports, and deliverables, as required by the team 
leader.  
 
E.  International Financial Sector Information Technology Expert (3 person-months) 
5.  The expert should have significant experience in developing and implementing financial 
sector  information  systems,  with  a  focus  on  capital  market  and  payment  and  settlement 
systems.  Experience in the Asia and Pacific region is preferable. The expert’s duties will 
include the following: 
 
(i)  In coordination with the team leader and other international experts, prepare a 
draft  diagnostic  study  on  the  current  information  technology  framework  and 
platform  for  the  capital  market  and  the  supporting  payment  and  settlement

(ii)  In coordination with the Government and the payment and settlement expert,

(iii)  Prepare  a  report  summarizing  the  findings  and  making  recommendations  to

(b) support the establishment of money and interbank markets; and (c) develop a 
suitable information and communications technology platform for trading and for 
payment and settlement.
